unnormalised: **The Great Indian Standard Time Stretch: Or, Why Meetings Always Start Late**
normalised: **The Great Indian Standard Time Stretch: Or, Why Meetings Always Start Late**

unnormalised: Let's face it, folks. In India, time is more of a suggestion than a rigid constraint. Especially in the office. Scheduling a meeting at, say, 10:00 AM? Bless your optimistic heart. You're practically inviting chaos. The real start time? Closer to 10:15 AM, minimum. We like to call this the Indian Standard Time (IST) stretch. A 10 o’clock meeting translates to 10:15am plus buffer for chai break (10-15 mins) and another 5 mins for random catch up, totalling 10:35am.
normalised: Let us face it, folks. In India, time is more of a suggestion than a rigid constraint. Especially in the office. Scheduling a meeting at, say, ten A-M? Bless your optimistic heart. You are practically inviting chaos. The real start time? Closer to ten fifteen A-M, minimum. We like to call this the Indian Standard Time (I-S-T) stretch. A ten o’clock meeting translates to ten fifteen A-M plus buffer for chai break (ten to fifteen minutes) and another five minutes for random catch up, totalling ten thirty five A-M.

unnormalised: It's not just about deliberate tardiness, though. Oh no, it's a complex tapestry woven with cultural nuances, traffic woes, and the ever-present "urgent work" that always seems to pop up five minutes before any scheduled event. Blame it on the monsoon traffic. Blame it on the power cut (scheduled or otherwise). Blame it on your colleague who got stuck in an auto-rickshaw jam. Whatever the reason, arriving precisely at 10:00 AM is practically an act of rebellion.

Whatever the reason, arriving precisely at ten A-M is practically an act of rebellion.

unnormalised: Consider this common scenario: You meticulously schedule a team meeting for 2:00 PM. You even send out reminders, CC-ing your manager and the entire team, 24 hours in advance, and then again at 1:50 PM. You arrive five minutes early, feeling smug and prepared. The conference room? Deserted. Except for Rajesh from accounts, who's scrolling through Instagram and muttering something about "just five more minutes."

The conference room? Deserted. Except for Rajesh from accounts, who is scrolling through Instagram and muttering something about "just five more minutes."

unnormalised: By 2:10 PM, a few stragglers wander in, offering vague apologies about "being held up." By 2:20 PM, the actual meeting begins, although half the attendees are still fiddling with their laptops and whispering about last night’s IPL match. The agenda you so carefully prepared? Largely ignored as the conversation meanders through topics like the latest Bollywood release and the office chaiwala's surprisingly accurate cricket predictions.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on the time zones of our virtual teams. A "quick call" scheduled for 11:30 AM IST magically transforms into a 1:00 PM slugfest, thanks to time differences, "client emergencies," and the general reluctance to start anything before a hearty lunch. By then most people are so sleepy, that instead of getting things done, we’re all just nodding our heads like bobble head dolls.

unnormalised: Then there's the concept of "preponing." In the West, they postpone. In India, we *prepone*. Because why push something back when you can inexplicably move it *forward* at the last minute, throwing everyone's carefully laid plans into complete disarray? "Meeting preponed to 9:00 AM," the email cheerfully announces, without any consideration for the fact that half the team is still battling morning traffic.

unnormalised: So, what's the solution? Honestly, I have no clue. Perhaps we should all start scheduling meetings for an hour *before* we actually want them to begin. Or maybe we should just embrace the chaos and accept that, in the Indian office, time is a fluid, ever-changing concept, much like the plot of a typical Ekta Kapoor serial. One thing I am sure of is that 2:00 PM will never mean 2:00 PM in reality, it means 2:30pm.

unnormalised: At the end of the day, it’s not about being late per se; it’s more about prioritisation. Family emergencies, religious festivals, political rallies, traffic delays and the list goes on. All this leads to delays and rescheduling that impacts work schedules. Until these socio-economic factors are resolved, the Great Indian Standard Time Stretch will likely continue.
